original_data.question: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with the chief complaint of a high fever for several days. In addition to the fever, he has had malaise, chest pain, and a dry cough. He recently went on vacation to South America but has returned to his job delivering packages. He has several friends who recently had influenza. Hi temperature is 102.8째F (39.3 째C), blood pressure is 137/80 mmHg, pulse is 104/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98%. Chest exam reveals a deep noise found bilaterally in the lung bases. Chest radiograph reveals a wider area of opacity near the heart and bilateral lung infiltrates. Which of the following is characteristic of the most likely organism responsible for this patient's symptoms?

model_response:
The patient most likely has Legionnaires' disease, which is caused by Legionella pneumophila. Legionella is a gram-negative rod that stains with difficulty. It is found in natural bodies of fresh water and can be concentrated by passing the water through charcoal. It can be isolated on routine laboratory media if the media are heated to 45째C (unlike Mycoplasma, Legionella grows better at 35째C). The organism has a D-glutamate capsule that prevents phagocytosis by WBCs. The organism can be identified by direct fluorescent antibody staining of respiratory secretions. Legionella can survive and multiply inside free-living amebas, which may be an important reservoir. The organism produces a toxin that is chemically similar to diphtheria toxin. The polyribosyl-ribitol-phosphate capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae is a virulence factor that protects it from phagocytosis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative rod that is found in moist environments, such as shower heads and sinks. It is a common cause of pneumonia in patients with cystic fibrosis. It does not have a D-glutamate capsule or a polysaccharide capsule. It is a strict aerobe and does not grow on routine laboratory media if the carbon dioxide tension is not carefully controlled. It is often multidrug-resistant. Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative rod that is a common cause of pneumonia in patients with chronic lung disease. It does not have a D-glutamate capsule or a polysaccharide capsule. It is a strict aerobe and does not grow on routine laboratory media if the carbon dioxide tension is not carefully controlled. It is often multidrug-resistant. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a small pleomorphic rod that lacks a cell wall and is therefore not visible on Gram's stain. It is found in the throat of about half of all healthy adults, who carry the organism without symptoms. It is transmitted person to person via respiratory droplets. Mycoplasma causes atypical pneumonia, which is usually not severe. It does not have a D-glutamate capsule or a polysaccharide capsule.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
The primary reason for a patient visit.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness, an out-of-sorts feeling.
Pressure, burning, or numbness in the chest.
A cough that is not accompanied by expectorated secretions.
Leisure time away from work devoted to rest or pleasure.
The southern continent of the Western Hemisphere, extending southward from the Colombia-Panama border.
Crafts, trades, professions, or other means of earning a living.
Written programs or procedures or rules and associated documentation pertaining to the operation of a computer system and that are stored in read/write memory.
Persons whom one knows, likes, and trusts.

A group of islands in Polynesia, in the north central Pacific Ocean, comprising eight major and 114 minor islands, largely volcanic and coral. Its capital is Honolulu. It was first reached by Polynesians about 500 A.D. It was discovered and named the Sandwich Islands in 1778 by Captain Cook. The islands were united under the rule of King Kamehameha 1795-1819 and requested annexation to the United States in 1893 when a provisional government was set up. Hawaii was established as a territory in 1900 and admitted as a state in 1959. The name is from the Polynesian Owhyhii, place of the gods, with reference to the two volcanoes Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa, regarded as the abode of the gods. (From Webster's New Geographical Dictionary, 1988, p493 & Room, Brewer's Dictionary of Names, 1992, p2330)
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
The bottom concave portion of the lung that is situated on the convexity of the diaphragm.
The quality of being opaque to a degree; the degree to which something reduces the passage of light.
The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
A living entity.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
